trans-unit.source: Using Azure PowerShell with Azure Storage | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Using Azure PowerShell with Azure Storage | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the Azure PowerShell cmdlets for Azure Storage to create and manage storage accounts; work with blobs, tables, queues, and files; configure and query storage analytics, and create shared access signatures.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the Azure PowerShell cmdlets for Azure Storage to create and manage storage accounts; work with blobs, tables, queues, and files; configure and query storage analytics, and create shared access signatures.

trans-unit.source: In this guide, we’ll explore how to use the <linkText>Azure Service Management Cmdlets for Storage</linkText><title></title> to perform a variety of development and administration tasks with Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: In this guide, we’ll explore how to use the <linkText>Azure Service Management Cmdlets for Storage</linkText><title></title> to perform a variety of development and administration tasks with Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: Azure PowerShell is a module that provides cmdlets to manage Azure through Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Azure PowerShell is a module that provides cmdlets to manage Azure through Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: It is a task-based command-line shell and scripting language designed especially for system administration.
trans-unit.target: It is a task-based command-line shell and scripting language designed especially for system administration.

trans-unit.source: With PowerShell, you can easily control and automate the administration of your Azure services and applications.
trans-unit.target: With PowerShell, you can easily control and automate the administration of your Azure services and applications.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can use the cmdlets to perform the same tasks that you can perform through the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: For example, you can use the cmdlets to perform the same tasks that you can perform through the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: This guide assumes that you have prior experience using <linkText>Azure Storage</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Windows PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: This guide assumes that you have prior experience using <linkText>Azure Storage</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Windows PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The guide provides a number of scripts to demonstrate the usage of PowerShell with Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: The guide provides a number of scripts to demonstrate the usage of PowerShell with Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: You should update the script variables based on your configuration before running each script.
trans-unit.target: You should update the script variables based on your configuration before running each script.

trans-unit.source: The first section in this guide provides a quick glance at Azure Storage and PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: The first section in this guide provides a quick glance at Azure Storage and PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: For detailed information and instructions, start from the <linkText>Prerequisites for using Azure PowerShell with Azure Storage</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For detailed information and instructions, start from the <linkText>Prerequisites for using Azure PowerShell with Azure Storage</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This section shows you how to access Azure Storage via PowerShell in 5 minutes.
trans-unit.target: This section shows you how to access Azure Storage via PowerShell in 5 minutes.

trans-unit.source: New to Azure: Get a Microsoft Azure subscription and a Microsoft account associated with that subscription.
trans-unit.target: New to Azure: Get a Microsoft Azure subscription and a Microsoft account associated with that subscription.

trans-unit.source: For information on Azure purchase options, see <linkText>Free Trial</linkText><title></title>, <linkText>Purchase Options</linkText><title></title>, and <linkText>Member Offers</linkText><title></title> (for members of MSDN, Microsoft Partner Network, and BizSpark, and other Microsoft programs).
trans-unit.target: For information on Azure purchase options, see <linkText>Free Trial</linkText><title></title>, <linkText>Purchase Options</linkText><title></title>, and <linkText>Member Offers</linkText><title></title> (for members of MSDN, Microsoft Partner Network, and BizSpark, and other Microsoft programs).

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Manage Accounts, Subscriptions, and Administrative Roles</linkText><title></title> for more information about Azure subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Manage Accounts, Subscriptions, and Administrative Roles</linkText><title></title> for more information about Azure subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: After creating a Microsoft Azure subscription and account:
trans-unit.target: After creating a Microsoft Azure subscription and account:

trans-unit.source: Download and install <linkText>Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Download and install <linkText>Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Start Windows PowerShell Integrated Scripting Environment (ISE): In your local computer, go to the Start menu.
trans-unit.target: Start Windows PowerShell Integrated Scripting Environment (ISE): In your local computer, go to the Start menu.

trans-unit.source: Type Administrative Tools and click to run it.
trans-unit.target: Type Administrative Tools and click to run it.

trans-unit.source: In the Administrative Tools window, right-click Windows PowerShell ISE, click Run as Administrator.
trans-unit.target: In the Administrative Tools window, right-click Windows PowerShell ISE, click Run as Administrator.

trans-unit.source: In Windows PowerShell ISE, click File > New to create a new script file.
trans-unit.target: In Windows PowerShell ISE, click File > New to create a new script file.

trans-unit.source: Now, we’ll give you a simple script that shows basic PowerShell commands to access Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: Now, we’ll give you a simple script that shows basic PowerShell commands to access Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: The script will first ask your Azure account credentials to add your Azure account to the local PowerShell environment.
trans-unit.target: The script will first ask your Azure account credentials to add your Azure account to the local PowerShell environment.

trans-unit.source: Then, the script will set the default Azure subscription and create a new storage account in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Then, the script will set the default Azure subscription and create a new storage account in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Next, the script will create a new container in this new storage account and upload an existing image file (blob) to that container.
trans-unit.target: Next, the script will create a new container in this new storage account and upload an existing image file (blob) to that container.

trans-unit.source: After the script lists all blobs in that container, it will create a new destination directory in your local computer and download the image file.
trans-unit.target: After the script lists all blobs in that container, it will create a new destination directory in your local computer and download the image file.

trans-unit.source: In the following code section, select the script between the remarks #begin and #end.
trans-unit.target: In the following code section, select the script between the remarks #begin and #end.

trans-unit.source: Press CTRL+C to copy it to the clipboard.
trans-unit.target: Press CTRL+C to copy it to the clipboard.

trans-unit.source: In Windows PowerShell ISE, press CTRL+V to copy the script.
trans-unit.target: In Windows PowerShell ISE, press CTRL+V to copy the script.

trans-unit.source: Click File > Save.
trans-unit.target: Click File > Save.

trans-unit.source: In the Save As dialog window, type the name of the script file, such as "mystoragescript".
trans-unit.target: In the Save As dialog window, type the name of the script file, such as "mystoragescript".

trans-unit.source: Click Save.
trans-unit.target: Click Save.

trans-unit.source: Now, you need to update the script variables based on your configuration settings.
trans-unit.target: Now, you need to update the script variables based on your configuration settings.

trans-unit.source: You must update the $SubscriptionName variable with your own subscription.
trans-unit.target: You must update the $SubscriptionName variable with your own subscription.

trans-unit.source: You can keep the other variables as specified in the script or update them as you wish.
trans-unit.target: You can keep the other variables as specified in the script or update them as you wish.

trans-unit.source: $SubscriptionName: You must update this variable with your own subscription name.
trans-unit.target: $SubscriptionName: You must update this variable with your own subscription name.

trans-unit.source: Follow one of the following three ways to locate the name of your subscription:
trans-unit.target: Follow one of the following three ways to locate the name of your subscription:

trans-unit.source: a.
trans-unit.target: a.

trans-unit.source: In Windows PowerShell ISE, click File > New to create a new script file.
trans-unit.target: In Windows PowerShell ISE, click File > New to create a new script file.

trans-unit.source: Copy the following script to the new script file and click Debug > Run.
trans-unit.target: Copy the following script to the new script file and click Debug > Run.

trans-unit.source: The following script will first ask your Azure account credentials to add your Azure account to the local PowerShell environment and then show all the subscriptions that are connected to the local PowerShell session.
trans-unit.target: The following script will first ask your Azure account credentials to add your Azure account to the local PowerShell environment and then show all the subscriptions that are connected to the local PowerShell session.

trans-unit.target: Take a note of the name of the subscription that you want to use while following this tutorial:

trans-unit.target: b.

trans-unit.source: Currently, Azure supports two portals: the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title> and the <linkText>Azure Preview Portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Currently, Azure supports two portals: the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title> and the <linkText>Azure Preview Portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: If you sign in to the current Azure Management Portal, scroll down and click Settings on the left side of the portal.
trans-unit.target: If you sign in to the current Azure Management Portal, scroll down and click Settings on the left side of the portal.

trans-unit.source: Click Subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: Click Subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: Copy the name of subscription that you want to use while running the scripts given in this guide.
trans-unit.target: Copy the name of subscription that you want to use while running the scripts given in this guide.

trans-unit.target: If you sign in to the Azure Preview Portal, in the Hub menu on the left, click BROWSE.

trans-unit.target: Then, click Everything, click Subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: Copy the name of subscription that you want to use while running the scripts in this guide.
trans-unit.target: Copy the name of subscription that you want to use while running the scripts in this guide.

trans-unit.source: $StorageAccountName: Use the given name in the script or enter a new name for your storage account.
trans-unit.target: $StorageAccountName: Use the given name in the script or enter a new name for your storage account.

trans-unit.source: Important: The name of the storage account must be unique in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Important: The name of the storage account must be unique in Azure.

trans-unit.source: It must be lowercase, too!
trans-unit.target: It must be lowercase, too!

trans-unit.source: $Location: Use the given "West US" in the script or choose other Azure locations, such as East US, North Europe, and so on.
trans-unit.target: $Location: Use the given "West US" in the script or choose other Azure locations, such as East US, North Europe, and so on.

trans-unit.source: $ContainerName: Use the given name in the script or enter a new name for your container.
trans-unit.target: $ContainerName: Use the given name in the script or enter a new name for your container.

trans-unit.source: $ImageToUpload: Enter a path to a picture on your local computer, such as: "C:\Images\HelloWorld.png".
trans-unit.target: $ImageToUpload: Enter a path to a picture on your local computer, such as: "C:\Images\HelloWorld.png".

trans-unit.source: $DestinationFolder: Enter a path to a local directory to store files downloaded from Azure Storage, such as: “C:\DownloadImages”.
trans-unit.target: $DestinationFolder: Enter a path to a local directory to store files downloaded from Azure Storage, such as: “C:\DownloadImages”.

trans-unit.source: After updating the script variables in the "mystoragescript.ps1" file, click File > Save.
trans-unit.target: After updating the script variables in the "mystoragescript.ps1" file, click File > Save.

trans-unit.source: Then, click Debug > Run or press F5 to run the script.
trans-unit.target: Then, click Debug > Run or press F5 to run the script.

trans-unit.source: After the script runs, you should have a local destination folder that includes the downloaded image file.
trans-unit.target: After the script runs, you should have a local destination folder that includes the downloaded image file.

trans-unit.source: The "Getting started with Azure Storage and PowerShell in 5 minutes" section provided a quick introduction on how to use Azure PowerShell with Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: The "Getting started with Azure Storage and PowerShell in 5 minutes" section provided a quick introduction on how to use Azure PowerShell with Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: For detailed information and instructions, we encourage you to read the following sections.
trans-unit.target: For detailed information and instructions, we encourage you to read the following sections.

trans-unit.source: You need an Azure subscription and account to run the PowerShell cmdlets given in this guide, as described above.
trans-unit.target: You need an Azure subscription and account to run the PowerShell cmdlets given in this guide, as described above.

trans-unit.source: Azure PowerShell is a module that provides cmdlets to manage Azure through Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Azure PowerShell is a module that provides cmdlets to manage Azure through Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: For information on installing and setting up Azure PowerShell, see <linkText>How to install and configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For information on installing and setting up Azure PowerShell, see <linkText>How to install and configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you download and install or upgrade to the latest Azure PowerShell module before using this guide.
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you download and install or upgrade to the latest Azure PowerShell module before using this guide.

trans-unit.source: You can run the cmdlets in the Azure PowerShell console, the standard Windows PowerShell console, or the Windows PowerShell Integrated Scripting Environment (ISE).
trans-unit.target: You can run the cmdlets in the Azure PowerShell console, the standard Windows PowerShell console, or the Windows PowerShell Integrated Scripting Environment (ISE).

trans-unit.source: For example, to open an Azure PowerShell console, go to the Start menu, type Microsoft Azure PowerShell, right-click and click Run as administrator.
trans-unit.target: For example, to open an Azure PowerShell console, go to the Start menu, type Microsoft Azure PowerShell, right-click and click Run as administrator.

trans-unit.source: To open Windows PowerShell ISE, go to the Start menu, type Administrative Tools and click to run it.
trans-unit.target: To open Windows PowerShell ISE, go to the Start menu, type Administrative Tools and click to run it.

trans-unit.source: In the Administrative Tools window, right-click Windows PowerShell ISE, click Run as Administrator.
trans-unit.target: In the Administrative Tools window, right-click Windows PowerShell ISE, click Run as Administrator.

trans-unit.source: To manage Azure Storage using Azure PowerShell, you need to authenticate your client environment with Azure via Azure Active Directory Authentication or Certificate-based Authentication.
trans-unit.target: To manage Azure Storage using Azure PowerShell, you need to authenticate your client environment with Azure via Azure Active Directory Authentication or Certificate-based Authentication.

trans-unit.source: For detailed information, see <linkText>How to install and configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title> tutorial.
trans-unit.target: For detailed information, see <linkText>How to install and configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title> tutorial.

trans-unit.source: This guide uses the Azure Active Directory authentication.
trans-unit.target: This guide uses the Azure Active Directory authentication.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure PowerShell console or in Windows PowerShell ISE, type the following command to add your Azure account to the local PowerShell environment:
trans-unit.target: In the Azure PowerShell console or in Windows PowerShell ISE, type the following command to add your Azure account to the local PowerShell environment:

trans-unit.source: Add-AzureAccount
trans-unit.target: Add-AzureAccount

trans-unit.source: In the “Sign in to Microsoft Azure” window, type the email address and password associated with your account.
trans-unit.target: In the “Sign in to Microsoft Azure” window, type the email address and password associated with your account.

trans-unit.source: Azure authenticates and saves the credential information, and then closes the window.
trans-unit.target: Azure authenticates and saves the credential information, and then closes the window.

trans-unit.source: Next, run the following command to view the Azure accounts in your local PowerShell environment, and verify that your account is listed:
trans-unit.target: Next, run the following command to view the Azure accounts in your local PowerShell environment, and verify that your account is listed:

trans-unit.source: Get-AzureAccount
trans-unit.target: Get-AzureAccount

trans-unit.source: Then, run the following cmdlet to view all the subscriptions that are connected to the local PowerShell session, and verify that your subscription is listed:
trans-unit.target: Then, run the following cmdlet to view all the subscriptions that are connected to the local PowerShell session, and verify that your subscription is listed:

trans-unit.source: Get-AzureSubscription | Format-Table SubscriptionName, IsDefault, IsCurrent, CurrentStorageAccountName
trans-unit.target: Get-AzureSubscription | Format-Table SubscriptionName, IsDefault, IsCurrent, CurrentStorageAccountName

trans-unit.source: To set a default Azure subscription, run the Select-AzureSubscription cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: To set a default Azure subscription, run the Select-AzureSubscription cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: Verify the name of the default subscription by running the Get-AzureSubscription cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: Verify the name of the default subscription by running the Get-AzureSubscription cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: Get-AzureSubscription -Default
trans-unit.target: Get-AzureSubscription -Default

trans-unit.source: To see all the available PowerShell cmdlets for Azure Storage, run:
trans-unit.target: To see all the available PowerShell cmdlets for Azure Storage, run:

trans-unit.source: Get-Command -Module Azure -Noun *Storage*
trans-unit.target: Get-Command -Module Azure -Noun *Storage*

trans-unit.source: To use Azure storage, you will need a storage account.
trans-unit.target: To use Azure storage, you will need a storage account.

trans-unit.source: You can create a new Azure storage account after you have configured your computer to connect to your subscription.
trans-unit.target: You can create a new Azure storage account after you have configured your computer to connect to your subscription.

trans-unit.source: Run the Get-AzureLocation cmdlet to find all the available datacenter locations:
trans-unit.target: Run the Get-AzureLocation cmdlet to find all the available datacenter locations:

trans-unit.source: Get-AzureLocation | format-Table -Property Name, AvailableServices, StorageAccountTypes
trans-unit.target: Get-AzureLocation | format-Table -Property Name, AvailableServices, StorageAccountTypes

trans-unit.source: Next, run the New-AzureStorageAccount cmdlet to create a new storage account.
trans-unit.target: Next, run the New-AzureStorageAccount cmdlet to create a new storage account.

trans-unit.source: The following example creates a new storage account in the "West US" datacenter.
trans-unit.target: The following example creates a new storage account in the "West US" datacenter.

trans-unit.source: The name of your storage account must be unique within Azure and must be lowercase.
trans-unit.target: The name of your storage account must be unique within Azure and must be lowercase.

trans-unit.source: For naming conventions and restrictions, see <linkText>About Azure Storage Accounts</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Naming and Referencing Containers, Blobs, and Metadata</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For naming conventions and restrictions, see <linkText>About Azure Storage Accounts</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Naming and Referencing Containers, Blobs, and Metadata</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You can have multiple storage accounts in your subscription.
trans-unit.target: You can have multiple storage accounts in your subscription.

trans-unit.source: You can choose one of them and set it as the default storage account for all the storage commands in the same PowerShell session.
trans-unit.target: You can choose one of them and set it as the default storage account for all the storage commands in the same PowerShell session.

trans-unit.source: This enables you to run the Azure PowerShell storage commands without specifying the storage context explicitly.
trans-unit.target: This enables you to run the Azure PowerShell storage commands without specifying the storage context explicitly.

trans-unit.source: To set a default storage account for your subscription, you can run the Set-AzureSubscription cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To set a default storage account for your subscription, you can run the Set-AzureSubscription cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Next, run the Get-AzureSubscription cmdlet to verify that the storage account is associated with your default subscription account.
trans-unit.target: Next, run the Get-AzureSubscription cmdlet to verify that the storage account is associated with your default subscription account.

trans-unit.source: This command returns the subscription properties on the current subscription including its current storage account.
trans-unit.target: This command returns the subscription properties on the current subscription including its current storage account.

trans-unit.source: Each Azure subscription can have up to 100 storage accounts.
trans-unit.target: Each Azure subscription can have up to 100 storage accounts.

trans-unit.source: For the most up-to-date information on limits, see <linkText>Azure Subscription and Service Limits, Quotas, and Constraints</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For the most up-to-date information on limits, see <linkText>Azure Subscription and Service Limits, Quotas, and Constraints</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Run the following cmdlet to find out the name and status of the storage accounts in the current subscription:
trans-unit.target: Run the following cmdlet to find out the name and status of the storage accounts in the current subscription:

trans-unit.source: Azure storage context is an object in PowerShell to encapsulate the storage credentials.
trans-unit.target: Azure storage context is an object in PowerShell to encapsulate the storage credentials.

trans-unit.source: Using a storage context while running any subsequent cmdlet enables you to authenticate your request without specifying the storage account and its access key explicitly.
trans-unit.target: Using a storage context while running any subsequent cmdlet enables you to authenticate your request without specifying the storage account and its access key explicitly.

trans-unit.source: You can create a storage context in many ways, such as using storage account name and access key, shared access signature (SAS) token, connection string, or anonymous.
trans-unit.target: You can create a storage context in many ways, such as using storage account name and access key, shared access signature (SAS) token, connection string, or anonymous.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>New-AzureStorageContext</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>New-AzureStorageContext</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Use one of the following three ways to create a storage context:
trans-unit.target: Use one of the following three ways to create a storage context:

trans-unit.source: Run the <linkText>Get-AzureStorageKey</linkText><title></title> cmdlet to find out the primary storage access key for your Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: Run the <linkText>Get-AzureStorageKey</linkText><title></title> cmdlet to find out the primary storage access key for your Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: Next, call the <linkText>New-AzureStorageContext</linkText><title></title> cmdlet to create a storage context:
trans-unit.target: Next, call the <linkText>New-AzureStorageContext</linkText><title></title> cmdlet to create a storage context:

trans-unit.source: Generate a shared access signature token for an Azure storage container and use it to create a storage context:
trans-unit.target: Generate a shared access signature token for an Azure storage container and use it to create a storage context:

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>New-AzureStorageContainerSASToken</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Shared Access Signatures, Part 1: Understanding the SAS Model </linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>New-AzureStorageContainerSASToken</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Shared Access Signatures, Part 1: Understanding the SAS Model </linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In some cases, you may want to specify the service endpoints when you create a new storage context.
trans-unit.target: In some cases, you may want to specify the service endpoints when you create a new storage context.

trans-unit.source: This might be necessary when you have registered a custom domain name for your storage account with the Blob service or you want to use a shared access signature for accessing storage resources.
trans-unit.target: This might be necessary when you have registered a custom domain name for your storage account with the Blob service or you want to use a shared access signature for accessing storage resources.

trans-unit.source: Set the service endpoints in a connection string and use it to create a new storage context as shown below:
trans-unit.target: Set the service endpoints in a connection string and use it to create a new storage context as shown below:

trans-unit.source: For more information on how to configure a storage connection string, see <linkText>Configuring Connection Strings</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on how to configure a storage connection string, see <linkText>Configuring Connection Strings</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Now that you have set up your computer and learned how to manage subscriptions and storage accounts using Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have set up your computer and learned how to manage subscriptions and storage accounts using Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Go to the next section to learn how to manage Azure blobs and blob snapshots.
trans-unit.target: Go to the next section to learn how to manage Azure blobs and blob snapshots.

trans-unit.source: Azure Blob storage is a service for storing large amounts of unstructured data, such as text or binary data, that can be accessed from anywhere in the world via HTTP or HTTPS.
trans-unit.target: Azure Blob storage is a service for storing large amounts of unstructured data, such as text or binary data, that can be accessed from anywhere in the world via HTTP or HTTPS.

trans-unit.source: This section assumes that you are already familiar with the Azure Blob Storage Service concepts.
trans-unit.target: This section assumes that you are already familiar with the Azure Blob Storage Service concepts.

trans-unit.source: For detailed information, see <linkText>How to use Blob Storage from .NET</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Blob Service Concepts</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For detailed information, see <linkText>How to use Blob Storage from .NET</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Blob Service Concepts</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Every blob in Azure storage must be in a container.
trans-unit.target: Every blob in Azure storage must be in a container.

trans-unit.source: You can create a private container using the New-AzureStorageContainer cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: You can create a private container using the New-AzureStorageContainer cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: There are three levels of anonymous read access: Off, Blob, and Container.
trans-unit.target: There are three levels of anonymous read access: Off, Blob, and Container.

trans-unit.source: To prevent anonymous access to blobs, set the Permission parameter to Off.
trans-unit.target: To prevent anonymous access to blobs, set the Permission parameter to Off.

trans-unit.source: By default, the new container is private and can be accessed only by the account owner.
trans-unit.target: By default, the new container is private and can be accessed only by the account owner.

trans-unit.source: To allow anonymous public read access to blob resources, but not to container metadata or to the list of blobs in the container, set the Permission parameter to Blob.
trans-unit.target: To allow anonymous public read access to blob resources, but not to container metadata or to the list of blobs in the container, set the Permission parameter to Blob.

trans-unit.source: To allow full public read access to blob resources, container metadata, and the list of blobs in the container, set the Permission parameter to Container.
trans-unit.target: To allow full public read access to blob resources, container metadata, and the list of blobs in the container, set the Permission parameter to Container.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Manage Access to Azure Storage Resources</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Manage Access to Azure Storage Resources</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Azure Blob Storage supports block blobs and page blobs.
trans-unit.target: Azure Blob Storage supports block blobs and page blobs.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Understanding Block Blobs and Page Blobs</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Understanding Block Blobs and Page Blobs</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To upload blobs in to a container, you can use the <linkText>Set-AzureStorageBlobContent</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To upload blobs in to a container, you can use the <linkText>Set-AzureStorageBlobContent</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: By default, this command uploads the local files to a block blob.
trans-unit.target: By default, this command uploads the local files to a block blob.

trans-unit.source: You can copy blobs across storage accounts and regions asynchronously.
trans-unit.target: You can copy blobs across storage accounts and regions asynchronously.

trans-unit.source: The following example demonstrates how to copy blobs from one storage container to another in two different storage accounts.
trans-unit.target: The following example demonstrates how to copy blobs from one storage container to another in two different storage accounts.

trans-unit.source: Azure lets you create a snapshot of a blob.
trans-unit.target: Azure lets you create a snapshot of a blob.

trans-unit.source: A snapshot is a read-only version of a blob that's taken at a point in time.
trans-unit.target: A snapshot is a read-only version of a blob that's taken at a point in time.

trans-unit.source: Once a snapshot has been created, it can be read, copied, or deleted, but not modified.
trans-unit.target: Once a snapshot has been created, it can be read, copied, or deleted, but not modified.

trans-unit.source: Snapshots provide a way to back up a blob as it appears at a moment in time.
trans-unit.target: Snapshots provide a way to back up a blob as it appears at a moment in time.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Creating a Snapshot of a Blob</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Creating a Snapshot of a Blob</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To create a snaphot of a blob, first get a blob reference and then call the ICloudBlob.CreateSnapshot method on it.
trans-unit.target: To create a snaphot of a blob, first get a blob reference and then call the ICloudBlob.CreateSnapshot method on it.

trans-unit.source: The following example first sets variables for a storage account, and then creates a storage context.
trans-unit.target: The following example first sets variables for a storage account, and then creates a storage context.

trans-unit.source: Next, the example retrieves a blob reference using the <linkText>Get-AzureStorageBlob</linkText><title></title> cmdlet and runs the <linkText>ICloudBlob.CreateSnapshot</linkText><title></title> method to create a snapshot.
trans-unit.target: Next, the example retrieves a blob reference using the <linkText>Get-AzureStorageBlob</linkText><title></title> cmdlet and runs the <linkText>ICloudBlob.CreateSnapshot</linkText><title></title> method to create a snapshot.

trans-unit.source: You can create as many snapshots as you want for a blob.
trans-unit.target: You can create as many snapshots as you want for a blob.

trans-unit.source: You can list the snapshots associated with your blob to track your current snapshots.
trans-unit.target: You can list the snapshots associated with your blob to track your current snapshots.

trans-unit.source: The following example uses a predefined blob and calls the <linkText>Get-AzureStorageBlob</linkText><title></title> cmdlet to list the snapshots of that blob.
trans-unit.target: The following example uses a predefined blob and calls the <linkText>Get-AzureStorageBlob</linkText><title></title> cmdlet to list the snapshots of that blob.

trans-unit.source: You can copy a snapshot of a blob to restore the snapshot.
trans-unit.target: You can copy a snapshot of a blob to restore the snapshot.

trans-unit.source: For detailed information and restrictions, see <linkText>Creating a Snapshot of a Blob</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For detailed information and restrictions, see <linkText>Creating a Snapshot of a Blob</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Azure Table storage service is a NoSQL datastore, which you can use to store and query huge sets of structured, non-relational data.
trans-unit.target: Azure Table storage service is a NoSQL datastore, which you can use to store and query huge sets of structured, non-relational data.

trans-unit.source: The main components of the service are tables, entities, and properties.
trans-unit.target: The main components of the service are tables, entities, and properties.

trans-unit.source: A table is a collection of entities.
trans-unit.target: A table is a collection of entities.

trans-unit.source: An entity is a set of properties.
trans-unit.target: An entity is a set of properties.

trans-unit.source: Each entity can have up to 252 properties, which are all name-value pair.
trans-unit.target: Each entity can have up to 252 properties, which are all name-value pair.

trans-unit.source: This section assumes that you are already familiar with the Azure Table Storage Service concepts.
trans-unit.target: This section assumes that you are already familiar with the Azure Table Storage Service concepts.

trans-unit.source: For detailed information, see <linkText>Understanding the Table Service Data Model</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>How to use Table Storage from .NET</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For detailed information, see <linkText>Understanding the Table Service Data Model</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>How to use Table Storage from .NET</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In the following sub sections, you’ll learn how to manage Azure Table storage service using Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: In the following sub sections, you’ll learn how to manage Azure Table storage service using Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include creating, deleting, and retrieving tables, as well as adding, querying, and deleting table entities.
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include creating, deleting, and retrieving tables, as well as adding, querying, and deleting table entities.

trans-unit.source: Every table must reside in an Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: Every table must reside in an Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: The following example demonstrates how to create a table in Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: The following example demonstrates how to create a table in Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: The example first establishes a connection to Azure Storage using the storage account context, which includes the storage account name and its access key.
trans-unit.target: The example first establishes a connection to Azure Storage using the storage account context, which includes the storage account name and its access key.

trans-unit.source: Next, it uses the <linkText>New-AzureStorageTable</linkText><title></title> cmdlet to create a table in Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: Next, it uses the <linkText>New-AzureStorageTable</linkText><title></title> cmdlet to create a table in Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: You can query and retrieve one or all tables in a Storage account.
trans-unit.target: You can query and retrieve one or all tables in a Storage account.

trans-unit.source: The following example demonstrates how to retrieve a given table using the <linkText>Get-AzureStorageTable</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: The following example demonstrates how to retrieve a given table using the <linkText>Get-AzureStorageTable</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: If you call the Get-AzureStorageTable cmdlet without any parameters, it gets all storage tables for a Storage account.
trans-unit.target: If you call the Get-AzureStorageTable cmdlet without any parameters, it gets all storage tables for a Storage account.

trans-unit.source: You can delete a table from a storage account by using the <linkText>Remove-AzureStorageTable</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You can delete a table from a storage account by using the <linkText>Remove-AzureStorageTable</linkText><title></title> cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Currently, Azure PowerShell does not provide cmdlets to manage table entities directly.
trans-unit.target: Currently, Azure PowerShell does not provide cmdlets to manage table entities directly.

trans-unit.source: To perform operations on table entities, you can use the classes given in the [Azure Storage Client Library for .NET](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/wastorage30referencehome.aspx).
trans-unit.target: To perform operations on table entities, you can use the classes given in the [Azure Storage Client Library for .NET](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/wastorage30referencehome.aspx).

trans-unit.source: To add an entity to a table, first create an object that defines your entity properties.
trans-unit.target: To add an entity to a table, first create an object that defines your entity properties.

trans-unit.source: An entity can have up to 255 properties, including 3 system properties: PartitionKey, RowKey, and Timestamp.
trans-unit.target: An entity can have up to 255 properties, including 3 system properties: PartitionKey, RowKey, and Timestamp.

trans-unit.source: You are responsible for inserting and updating the values of PartitionKey and RowKey.
trans-unit.target: You are responsible for inserting and updating the values of PartitionKey and RowKey.

trans-unit.source: The server manages the value of Timestamp, which cannot be modified.
trans-unit.target: The server manages the value of Timestamp, which cannot be modified.

trans-unit.source: Together the PartitionKey and RowKey uniquely identify every entity within a table.
trans-unit.target: Together the PartitionKey and RowKey uniquely identify every entity within a table.

trans-unit.source: PartitionKey: Determines the partition that the entity is stored in.
trans-unit.target: PartitionKey: Determines the partition that the entity is stored in.

trans-unit.source: RowKey: Uniquely identifies the entity within the partition.
trans-unit.target: RowKey: Uniquely identifies the entity within the partition.

trans-unit.source: You may define up to 252 custom properties for an entity.
trans-unit.target: You may define up to 252 custom properties for an entity.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Understanding the Table Service Data Model</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Understanding the Table Service Data Model</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Azure Queue storage is a service for storing large numbers of messages that can be accessed from anywhere in the world via authenticated calls using HTTP or HTTPS.
trans-unit.target: Azure Queue storage is a service for storing large numbers of messages that can be accessed from anywhere in the world via authenticated calls using HTTP or HTTPS.

trans-unit.source: This section assumes that you are already familiar with the Azure Queue Storage Service concepts.
trans-unit.target: This section assumes that you are already familiar with the Azure Queue Storage Service concepts.

trans-unit.source: For detailed information, see <linkText>How to use Queue Storage from .NET</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For detailed information, see <linkText>How to use Queue Storage from .NET</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This section will show you how to manage Azure Queue storage service using Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: This section will show you how to manage Azure Queue storage service using Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include inserting and deleting queue messages, as well as creating, deleting, and retrieving queues.
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include inserting and deleting queue messages, as well as creating, deleting, and retrieving queues.

trans-unit.target: You can query and retrieve a specific queue or a list of all the queues in a Storage account.

trans-unit.target: If you call the <linkText>Get-AzureStorageQueue</linkText><title></title> cmdlet without any parameters, it gets a list of all the queues.

trans-unit.source: To delete a queue and all the messages contained in it, call the Remove-AzureStorageQueue cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To delete a queue and all the messages contained in it, call the Remove-AzureStorageQueue cmdlet.

trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to delete a specified queue using the Remove-AzureStorageQueue cmdlet.

trans-unit.target: Currently, Azure PowerShell does not provide cmdlets to manage queue messages directly.

trans-unit.target: To perform operations on queue messages, you can use the classes given in the [Azure Storage Client Library for .NET](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/wastorage30referencehome.aspx).

trans-unit.target: To insert a message into an existing queue, first create a new instance of the <linkText>Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Storage.Queue.CloudQueueMessage</linkText><title></title> class.

trans-unit.target: Next, call the <linkText>AddMessage</linkText><title></title> method.

trans-unit.source: A CloudQueueMessage can be created from either a string (in UTF-8 format) or a byte array.
trans-unit.target: A CloudQueueMessage can be created from either a string (in UTF-8 format) or a byte array.

trans-unit.target: If the queue exists, the <linkText>New-Object</linkText><title></title> cmdlet is used to create an instance of the <linkText>Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Storage.Queue.CloudQueueMessage</linkText><title></title> class.

trans-unit.target: Later, the example calls the <linkText>AddMessage</linkText><title></title> method on this message object to add it to a queue.

trans-unit.source: Here is code which retrieves a queue and inserts the message 'MessageInfo':
trans-unit.target: Here is code which retrieves a queue and inserts the message 'MessageInfo':

trans-unit.source: Your code de-queues a message from a queue in two steps.
trans-unit.target: Your code de-queues a message from a queue in two steps.

trans-unit.source: When you call the <linkText>Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Storage.Queue.CloudQueue.GetMessage</linkText><title></title> method, you get the next message in a queue.
trans-unit.target: When you call the <linkText>Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Storage.Queue.CloudQueue.GetMessage</linkText><title></title> method, you get the next message in a queue.

trans-unit.source: A message returned from GetMessage becomes invisible to any other code reading messages from this queue.
trans-unit.target: A message returned from GetMessage becomes invisible to any other code reading messages from this queue.

trans-unit.source: To finish removing the message from the queue, you must also call the <linkText>Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Storage.Queue.CloudQueue.DeleteMessage</linkText><title></title> method.
trans-unit.target: To finish removing the message from the queue, you must also call the <linkText>Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Storage.Queue.CloudQueue.DeleteMessage</linkText><title></title> method.

trans-unit.source: This two-step process of removing a message assures that if your code fails to process a message due to hardware or software failure, another instance of your code can get the same message and try again.
trans-unit.target: This two-step process of removing a message assures that if your code fails to process a message due to hardware or software failure, another instance of your code can get the same message and try again.

trans-unit.source: Your code calls DeleteMessage right after the message has been processed.
trans-unit.target: Your code calls DeleteMessage right after the message has been processed.

trans-unit.source: Azure File storage offers shared storage for applications using the standard SMB 2.1 protocol.
trans-unit.target: Azure File storage offers shared storage for applications using the standard SMB 2.1 protocol.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Azure virtual machines and cloud services can share file data across application components via mounted shares, and on-premises applications can access file data in a share via the File storage API or Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Azure virtual machines and cloud services can share file data across application components via mounted shares, and on-premises applications can access file data in a share via the File storage API or Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: For more information on Azure File storage, see <linkText>How to use Azure File storage</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>File Service REST API</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on Azure File storage, see <linkText>How to use Azure File storage</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>File Service REST API</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You can use <linkText>Azure Storage Analytics</linkText><title></title> to collect metrics for your Azure storage accounts and log data about requests sent to your storage account.
trans-unit.target: You can use <linkText>Azure Storage Analytics</linkText><title></title> to collect metrics for your Azure storage accounts and log data about requests sent to your storage account.

trans-unit.source: You can use storage metrics to monitor the health of a storage account, and storage logging to diagnose and troubleshoot issues with your storage account.
trans-unit.target: You can use storage metrics to monitor the health of a storage account, and storage logging to diagnose and troubleshoot issues with your storage account.

trans-unit.source: By default, storage metrics is not enabled for your storage services.
trans-unit.target: By default, storage metrics is not enabled for your storage services.

trans-unit.source: You can enable monitoring using either the Azure Management Portal, Windows PowerShell, or programmatically through a storage API.
trans-unit.target: You can enable monitoring using either the Azure Management Portal, Windows PowerShell, or programmatically through a storage API.

trans-unit.source: Storage logging happens server-side and enables you to record details for both successful and failed requests in your storage account.
trans-unit.target: Storage logging happens server-side and enables you to record details for both successful and failed requests in your storage account.

trans-unit.source: These logs enable you to see details of read, write, and delete operations against your tables, queues, and blobs as well as the reasons for failed requests.
trans-unit.target: These logs enable you to see details of read, write, and delete operations against your tables, queues, and blobs as well as the reasons for failed requests.

trans-unit.source: To learn how to enable and view Storage Metrics data using PowerShell, see <linkText>How to enable Storage Metrics using PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To learn how to enable and view Storage Metrics data using PowerShell, see <linkText>How to enable Storage Metrics using PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To learn how to enable and retrieve Storage Logging data using PowerShell, see <linkText>How to enable Storage Logging using PowerShell</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Finding your Storage Logging log data</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To learn how to enable and retrieve Storage Logging data using PowerShell, see <linkText>How to enable Storage Logging using PowerShell</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Finding your Storage Logging log data</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For detailed information on using Storage Metrics and Storage Logging to troubleshoot storage issues, see <linkText>Monitoring, Diagnosing, and Troubleshooting Microsoft Azure Storage</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For detailed information on using Storage Metrics and Storage Logging to troubleshoot storage issues, see <linkText>Monitoring, Diagnosing, and Troubleshooting Microsoft Azure Storage</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Shared access signatures are an important part of the security model for any application using Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: Shared access signatures are an important part of the security model for any application using Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: They are useful for providing limited permissions to your storage account to clients that should not have the account key.
trans-unit.target: They are useful for providing limited permissions to your storage account to clients that should not have the account key.

trans-unit.source: By default, only the owner of the storage account may access blobs, tables, and queues within that account.
trans-unit.target: By default, only the owner of the storage account may access blobs, tables, and queues within that account.

trans-unit.source: If your service or application needs to make these resources available to other clients without sharing your access key, you have three options:
trans-unit.target: If your service or application needs to make these resources available to other clients without sharing your access key, you have three options:

trans-unit.source: Set a container's permissions to permit anonymous read access to the container and its blobs.
trans-unit.target: Set a container's permissions to permit anonymous read access to the container and its blobs.

trans-unit.source: This is not allowed for tables or queues.
trans-unit.target: This is not allowed for tables or queues.

trans-unit.source: Use a shared access signature that grants restricted access rights to containers, blobs, queues, and tables for a specific time interval.
trans-unit.target: Use a shared access signature that grants restricted access rights to containers, blobs, queues, and tables for a specific time interval.

trans-unit.source: Use a stored access policy to obtain an additional level of control over shared access signatures for a container or its blobs, for a queue, or for a table.
trans-unit.target: Use a stored access policy to obtain an additional level of control over shared access signatures for a container or its blobs, for a queue, or for a table.

trans-unit.source: The stored access policy allows you to change the start time, expiry time, or permissions for a signature, or to revoke it after it has been issued.
trans-unit.target: The stored access policy allows you to change the start time, expiry time, or permissions for a signature, or to revoke it after it has been issued.

trans-unit.source: A shared access signature can be in one of two forms:
trans-unit.target: A shared access signature can be in one of two forms:

trans-unit.source: Ad hoc SAS: When you create an ad hoc SAS, the start time, expiry time, and permissions for the SAS are all specified on the SAS URI.
trans-unit.target: Ad hoc SAS: When you create an ad hoc SAS, the start time, expiry time, and permissions for the SAS are all specified on the SAS URI.

trans-unit.source: This type of SAS may be created on a container, blob, table, or queue and it is non-revokable.
trans-unit.target: This type of SAS may be created on a container, blob, table, or queue and it is non-revokable.

trans-unit.source: SAS with stored access policy: A stored access policy is defined on a resource container a blob container, table, or queue - and you can use it to manage constraints for one or more shared access signatures.
trans-unit.target: SAS with stored access policy: A stored access policy is defined on a resource container a blob container, table, or queue - and you can use it to manage constraints for one or more shared access signatures.

trans-unit.source: When you associate a SAS with a stored access policy, the SAS inherits the constraints - the start time, expiry time, and permissions - defined for the stored access policy.
trans-unit.target: When you associate a SAS with a stored access policy, the SAS inherits the constraints - the start time, expiry time, and permissions - defined for the stored access policy.

trans-unit.source: This type of SAS is revokable.
trans-unit.target: This type of SAS is revokable.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>the Shared Access Signatures tutorial</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Manage Access to Azure Storage Resources</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>the Shared Access Signatures tutorial</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Manage Access to Azure Storage Resources</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In the next sections, you will learn how to create a shared access signature token and stored access policy for Azure tables. Azure PowerShell provides similar cmdlets for containers, blobs, and queues as well. To run the scripts in this section, download the <linkText>Azure PowerShell version 0.8.14</linkText><title></title> or later.
trans-unit.target: In the next sections, you will learn how to create a shared access signature token and stored access policy for Azure tables. Azure PowerShell provides similar cmdlets for containers, blobs, and queues as well. To run the scripts in this section, download the <linkText>Azure PowerShell version 0.8.14</linkText><title></title> or later.

trans-unit.source: Use the New-AzureStorageTableStoredAccessPolicy cmdlet to create a new stored access policy.
trans-unit.target: Use the New-AzureStorageTableStoredAccessPolicy cmdlet to create a new stored access policy.

trans-unit.source: Then, call the <linkText>New-AzureStorageTableSASToken</linkText><title></title> cmdlet to create a new policy-based shared access signature token for an Azure Storage table.
trans-unit.target: Then, call the <linkText>New-AzureStorageTableSASToken</linkText><title></title> cmdlet to create a new policy-based shared access signature token for an Azure Storage table.

trans-unit.source: Use the <linkText>New-AzureStorageTableSASToken</linkText><title></title> cmdlet to create a new ad hoc (non-revokable) Shared Access Signature token for an Azure Storage table:
trans-unit.target: Use the <linkText>New-AzureStorageTableSASToken</linkText><title></title> cmdlet to create a new ad hoc (non-revokable) Shared Access Signature token for an Azure Storage table:

trans-unit.source: Use the New-AzureStorageTableStoredAccessPolicy cmdlet to create a new stored access policy for an Azure Storage table:
trans-unit.target: Use the New-AzureStorageTableStoredAccessPolicy cmdlet to create a new stored access policy for an Azure Storage table:

trans-unit.source: Use the Set-AzureStorageTableStoredAccessPolicy cmdlet to update an existing stored access policy for an Azure Storage table:
trans-unit.target: Use the Set-AzureStorageTableStoredAccessPolicy cmdlet to update an existing stored access policy for an Azure Storage table:

trans-unit.source: Use the Remove-AzureStorageTableStoredAccessPolicy cmdlet to delete a stored access policy on an Azure Storage table:
trans-unit.target: Use the Remove-AzureStorageTableStoredAccessPolicy cmdlet to delete a stored access policy on an Azure Storage table:

trans-unit.source: An Azure environment is an independent deployment of Microsoft Azure, such as <linkText>Azure Government for U.S. government</linkText><title></title>, <linkText>AzureCloud for global Azure</linkText><title></title>, and <linkText>AzureChinaCloud for Azure operated by 21Vianet in China</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: An Azure environment is an independent deployment of Microsoft Azure, such as <linkText>Azure Government for U.S. government</linkText><title></title>, <linkText>AzureCloud for global Azure</linkText><title></title>, and <linkText>AzureChinaCloud for Azure operated by 21Vianet in China</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You can deploy new Azure environments for U.S government and Azure China.
trans-unit.target: You can deploy new Azure environments for U.S government and Azure China.

trans-unit.source: To use Azure Storage with AzureChinaCloud, you need to create a storage context that is associated with AzureChinaCloud.
trans-unit.target: To use Azure Storage with AzureChinaCloud, you need to create a storage context that is associated with AzureChinaCloud.

trans-unit.source: Follow these steps to get you started:
trans-unit.target: Follow these steps to get you started:

trans-unit.source: Run the <linkText>Get-AzureEnvironment</linkText><title></title> cmdlet to see the available Azure environments:
trans-unit.target: Run the <linkText>Get-AzureEnvironment</linkText><title></title> cmdlet to see the available Azure environments:

trans-unit.source: Get-AzureEnvironment
trans-unit.target: Get-AzureEnvironment

trans-unit.source: Add an Azure China account to Windows PowerShell:
trans-unit.target: Add an Azure China account to Windows PowerShell:

trans-unit.source: Add-AzureAccount –Environment AzureChinaCloud
trans-unit.target: Add-AzureAccount –Environment AzureChinaCloud

trans-unit.source: Create a storage context for an AzureChinaCloud account:
trans-unit.target: Create a storage context for an AzureChinaCloud account:

trans-unit.source: To use Azure Storage with <linkText>U.S. Azure Government</linkText><title></title>, you should define a new environment and then create a new storage context with this environment:
trans-unit.target: To use Azure Storage with <linkText>U.S. Azure Government</linkText><title></title>, you should define a new environment and then create a new storage context with this environment:

trans-unit.source: Call the <linkText>Add-AzureEnvironment</linkText><title></title> cmdlet to create a new Azure environment for your private datacenter.
trans-unit.target: Call the <linkText>Add-AzureEnvironment</linkText><title></title> cmdlet to create a new Azure environment for your private datacenter.

trans-unit.source: Run the <linkText>New-AzureStorageContext</linkText><title></title> cmdlet to create a new storage context for this new environment as shown below.
trans-unit.target: Run the <linkText>New-AzureStorageContext</linkText><title></title> cmdlet to create a new storage context for this new environment as shown below.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see:
trans-unit.target: For more information, see:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Microsoft Azure Government Developer Guide</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Microsoft Azure Government Developer Guide</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Differences between AzureCloud for global Azure and AzureChinaCloud for Azure operated by 21Vianet in China</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Differences between AzureCloud for global Azure and AzureChinaCloud for Azure operated by 21Vianet in China</linkText><title></title>
